body_html:
@robertlugg Thank you for filing this issue.

The run command of the tfdbg command-line interface has a number of flags

  1. -n, which lets you execute the next session.run(), without debugger, e.g.,

    tfdbg> run -n

  2. -t, which allows you to run through a number session.run() calls without stopping in the debugger, e.g.,

    tfdbg> run -t 10

More details on the the two flags are at: https://www.tensorflow.org/programmers_guide/debugger#tfdbg_cli_frequently-used_commands
Are these two flags good enough for your purposes? If not, I'd like to hear why so I can see how we can make it better. Please let me know. Thanks.

Are these two flags good enough for your purposes? If not, I'd like to hear why so I can see how we can make it better. Please let me know. Thanks.
body:
@robertlugg Thank you for filing this issue. 

The `run` command of the tfdbg command-line interface has a number of flags

1. `-n`, which lets you execute the next session.run(), without debugger, e.g.,

    ```
    tfdbg> run -n
    ```

2. `-t`, which allows you to run through a number session.run() calls without stopping in the debugger, e.g.,

    ```
    tfdbg> run -t 10
    ```

More details on the the two flags are at: https://www.tensorflow.org/programmers_guide/debugger#tfdbg_cli_frequently-used_commands
Are these two flags good enough for your purposes? If not, I'd like to hear why so I can see how we can make it better. Please let me know. Thanks.
